text: For Sarah conceived, and bare Abraham a son in his old age, at the set time of which God had spoken to him.
text_kjv: For Sarah conceived, and bare Abraham a son in his old age, at the set time of which God had spoken to him.
text_niv: Sarah became pregnant and bore a son to Abraham in his old age, at the very time God had promised him.
text_esv: And Sarah conceived and bore Abraham a son in his old age at the time of which God had spoken to him.
text_nlt: She became pregnant, and she gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age. This happened at just the time God had said it would.
text_msg: Sarah became pregnant and gave Abraham a son in his old age, and at the very time God had set.
text_nasb: So Sarah conceived and bore a son to Abraham in his old age, at the appointed time of which God had spoken to him.
context: Genesis 21:2 unfolds against the backdrop of ancient Near Eastern patriarchal society. In this era, lineage and inheritance were paramount, primarily secured through male offspring. Barrenness was a devastating social and personal stigma, considered a sign of divine disfavor, resulting in a woman’s diminished status. The extended family structure placed enormous pressure on couples to produce heirs, ensuring the continuation of the family name and property. Abraham, a wealthy and influential chieftain, had already attained a venerable age, likely exceeding 100 years, when Isaac was born. In such cultures, virility was associated with strength and divine blessing. For a man of Abraham's age to father a child was not just unusual; it was considered miraculous. Sarah, past menopause according to ancient understandings, was similarly aged, further emphasizing the impossibility of the situation. This context highlights the profoundness of God’s intervention, a stark contrast to the prevailing social norms where such an event was utterly inconceivable. The 'set time' mentioned was likely a culturally understood timeframe, probably a year from the announcement, fitting with natural gestational periods but made supernatural in its occurrence. It also shows that God acts within time, not irrespective of it. God's covenant with Abraham promised descendants as numerous as the stars, a promise seemingly impossible given Sarah's barrenness. The birth of Isaac after such a long wait served as a powerful testament to God's faithfulness and power over natural limitations.
meaning: The theological meaning of Genesis 21:2 resonates deeply with themes of divine sovereignty, promise, and the nature of faith. The phrase 'Sarah conceived' underscores God's active intervention in human affairs. It wasn't simply a fortunate natural occurrence; it was a direct result of God's power overcoming natural limitations. This highlights God's control over life and death, fertility and barrenness. The fact that Abraham was 'in his old age' when Isaac was born reinforces the miraculous nature of the event. It emphasizes that God's promises are not bound by human capabilities or timelines. The birth defied all human expectation and reason, illustrating that God's power surpasses all earthly limitations. The 'set time' indicates divine precision and faithfulness. God fulfilled his promise precisely when he said he would, demonstrating his reliability and trustworthiness. This is a key element in understanding the Abrahamic covenant. It shows that God keeps His word, even when it seems impossible. Isaac's birth is not merely a personal blessing to Abraham and Sarah; it is a pivotal moment in salvation history. Isaac becomes the heir of the covenant promises, the one through whom God's blessings will extend to all nations. This verse foreshadows the ultimate fulfillment of God's promises in Jesus Christ, whose birth also defied human expectations, demonstrating the power and faithfulness of God. Sarah's conception showcases God's ability to bring life out of barrenness, mirroring the spiritual transformation He brings to those who trust in Him.
application: Genesis 21:2 carries profound implications for our modern lives. Firstly, it reminds us that God is not limited by our circumstances or perceived impossibilities. We often face situations that seem hopeless, where our own resources and abilities are insufficient. This verse encourages us to trust in God's power to overcome obstacles and fulfill His promises, even when the odds are stacked against us. Like Abraham and Sarah, we may have to wait patiently for God's timing, which can be challenging, especially in our instant gratification society. However, the 'set time' reminds us that God's timing is perfect and that He will act in accordance with His plan. This calls us to cultivate patience and trust in His sovereignty. The verse also speaks to the importance of faith. Abraham and Sarah were called to believe God's promise despite the apparent impossibility of it being fulfilled. Similarly, we are called to have faith in God's Word, even when we don't understand how He will work things out. Faith involves trusting in God's character and His ability to keep His promises. Furthermore, the verse encourages us to embrace the unexpected blessings that God may bring into our lives. Like Sarah, we may be surprised by God's goodness and provision. It is important to be open to the possibility of God working in unexpected ways and to be grateful for His blessings, no matter how they come. The story also speaks to perseverance. Abraham and Sarah didn't give up on God's promise, even after many years of waiting. We too should persevere in our faith, trusting that God will ultimately fulfill His purposes in our lives. This is a powerful message for those struggling with infertility, chronic illness, or other difficult situations. God sees your pain and hasn't forgotten you.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for reminding us through the story of Abraham and Sarah that nothing is impossible with you. We confess that we often limit you by our own understanding and expectations. Forgive us for our lack of faith and for doubting your power to work in our lives. Help us to trust in your timing and to believe that you are able to fulfill your promises, even when circumstances seem hopeless. Grant us the patience to wait on you and the wisdom to discern your will. Fill us with gratitude for your blessings and open our eyes to see your hand at work in our lives. Strengthen our faith and help us to persevere through trials, knowing that you are with us always. We offer this prayer in Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Sarah's barrenness serves as a narrative device highlighting God's power. It emphasizes that Isaac's birth was a divine intervention, not a natural occurrence. Symbolically, it can represent spiritual barrenness, where God brings life and hope where there seemed to be none.
faqs.question: Why was Sarah barren for so long, and what does it symbolize?

faqs.answer: The 'set time' signifies God's meticulous planning and timing. It underscores God's faithfulness in keeping His promises precisely when He intended. It demonstrates that God's actions are deliberate and purposeful, not random.
faqs.question: What is the significance of the 'set time' mentioned in the verse?

faqs.answer: Isaac's birth is a direct fulfillment of God's promise to make Abraham a father of many nations. He is the heir through whom the covenant blessings would flow, fulfilling a central component of God's divine plan.
faqs.question: How does the birth of Isaac relate to the promises God made to Abraham?

faqs.answer: Their advanced age underscores the miraculous nature of Isaac's conception and birth. It highlights that God's power transcends human limitations and defies natural laws, demonstrating His sovereignty over life.
faqs.question: What does Abraham and Sarah's age at the time of Isaac's birth emphasize?

faqs.answer: This verse offers hope by demonstrating that God's timing is perfect, even when it seems delayed. It encourages trust in His promises, reminding us that He can work miracles even after extended periods of waiting.
